questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of severe, retrosternal chest pain. She also has pain when swallowing solid food and medications. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, poorly-controlled asthma, and osteoporosis. She was recently admitted to the hospital for an acute asthma exacerbation that was treated with bronchodilators and a 7-day course of oral corticosteroids. Her current medications include aspirin, amlodipine, metformin, insulin, beclomethasone and albuterol inhalers, and alendronate. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the oral pharynx appears normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An upper endoscopy shows a single punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa at the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsies of the ulcer are taken. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral drug used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, which can cause esophagitis. However, upper endoscopy of CMV esophagitis classically shows multiple, linear ulcers at the lower esophageal sphincter, not a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa.

B) CORRECT:

Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) can directly injure the esophageal mucosa in case of prolonged contact and cause drug-induced esophagitis. The most appropriate next step in the management of this condition is to discontinue the offending drug, if possible, and observe for symptom improvement. Most cases will then heal without further intervention. To minimize recurrence, patients should switch to liquid formulations or take the medication with liquids or meals to minimize the risk of the drug tablet sticking in the esophagus. Remaining upright for 30 minutes after taking the drug is also effective. Other common medications that can cause drug-induced esophagitis include antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines, clindamycin), NSAIDs, potassium chloride, quinidine, and iron compounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is an antifungal drug used to treat Candida albicans infections, which can cause esophagitis. This patient has an increased risk of developing fungal infections due to the chronic use of a steroid inhaler for asthma control. However, upper endoscopy of Candida esophagitis classically shows small, raised, white plaques and oral thrush, not a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) such as pantoprazole are used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can cause retrosternal chest pain as seen in this case. However, upper endoscopy of GERD classically shows diffusely inflamed mucosa in the lower esophagus with mucosal breaks, not a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa. PPIs are often used as an adjunctive treatment for drug-induced esophagitis because GERD can exacerbate esophageal injuries; however, the effectiveness of this intervention is unclear.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as amlodipine induce muscle relaxation and decrease lower esophageal sphincter tone, which can increase the risk of developing drug-induced esophagitis. However, CCBs do not directly cause this condition; discontinuation of amlodipine is not the most appropriate next step in the management.

F) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal drug used to treat Candida albicans infections, which can cause esophagitis. This patient has an increased risk of developing fungal infections due to the chronic use of a steroid inhaler for asthma control. However, upper endoscopy of Candida esophagitis classically shows small, raised, white plaques and oral thrush, not a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa.
questions.hint: This patient has medication-induced esophagitis, a condition that typically manifests with retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia as seen in this case. Dysphagia is another common manifestation. The characteristic finding on upper endoscopy is a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa, often located at a site of anatomic narrowing (e.g., the gastroesophageal junction).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for difficulty swallowing and a burning sensation in her chest for the past 2 years. She has increased her fluid consumption to help with swallowing when eating. She reports having used both over-the-counter antacids and pantoprazole for 2 months without any relief of symptoms. She uses a daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroid and an albuterol inhaler as needed for allergic asthma. She is 170 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lbs); her BMI is 26 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Findings of an upper endoscopy are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of heartburn and dysphagia raises suspicion for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). However, symptoms of GERD usually improve with proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy. GERD commonly affects the distal esophagus, which may be normal or show evidence of esophagitis; endoscopic evaluation of the upper esophagus will often be normal. Other endoscopic findings in individuals with longstanding GERD include esophageal ulcers, strictures, Barrett esophagus, and/or esophageal adenocarcinoma, none of which are present in this patient.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Several linear erosions are visible in the lower esophagus.

These features are pathognomonic of erosive esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors may raise suspicion for herpes (HSV) esophagitis. However, HSV esophagitis is usually present in individuals who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Moreover, endoscopic evaluation of HSV esophagitis would show vesicles and multiple small superficial round/ovoid ulcers in the mid and distal esophagus that may coalesce to form diffuse superficial ulcers, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple well-circumscribed, confluent ulcers (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible in the distal (lower) esophagus.

These findings are consistent with herpes esophagitis. Histopathology is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors may raise suspicion for candida esophagitis. However, candida esophagitis is typically present in individuals who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Although this patient's inhaled corticosteroid increases the risk of oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is only rarely associated with esophageal candidiasis. Moreover, endoscopic evaluation of candida esophagitis would reveal white mucosal plaque-like lesions, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple confluent, white-gray plaques in a longitudinal pattern are visible.

These findings are characteristic of Candida esophagitis.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors raises suspicion for drug-induced esophagitis. However, endoscopic evaluation of drug-induced esophagitis would reveal a discrete punched-out ulcer surrounded by relatively normal mucosa that may be mildly inflamed. Moreover, common causes of drug-induced esophagitis include NSAIDs, bisphosphonates, tetracyclines, potassium chloride, and iron, none of which this patient is taking.

E) CORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors in an individual with a history of atopy are indicative of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). A diagnosis of EoE is further supported by the findings on this patient's endoscopy (trachealization of the esophagus, longitudinal furrows, friable mucosa). Individuals with EoE may also present with food impaction, reflux, and vomiting. An endoscopic esophageal biopsy will typically show an eosinophilic infiltrate. EoE is managed initially by avoidance of food triggers, topical glucocorticoids (e.g., PO fluticasone or PO budesonide), and mechanical dilation in the setting of esophageal stricture.

F) INCORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors may raise suspicion for cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis. However, CMV esophagitis usually manifests in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Moreover, endoscopic evaluation of CMV esophagitis would show large linear ulcerations in the distal esophagus that are typically shallow, which are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's upper endoscopy shows white, circumferential mucosal lesions (trachealization of the esophagus), mucosa fragility, and linear, longitudinal furrows.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 3-month history of upper abdominal pain and several episodes of food getting stuck in his throat. His mother says that he has lost some weight because of difficulty swallowing solid foods; he has had no difficulty swallowing liquids. Medical history is remarkable for asthma. He is allergic to peanuts. His only medication is a budesonide and formoterol inhaler. He is at the 50th percentile for height, weight, and BMI. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Upper endoscopy shows linear, longitudinal furrows and circumferential lesions of the esophageal mucosa. Esophageal biopsy samples are obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Twenty-four-hour esophageal pH monitoring is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in patients with persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy. GERD can manifest with epigastric pain and dysphagia, which are seen in this patient. However, upper endoscopy findings in GERD include mucosal erosions and strictures rather than linear, longitudinal furrows and circumferential lesions. Moreover, this patient's age and allergic disposition are highly suggestive of EoE.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoid therapy is not a recommended treatment for EoE because of its known side effects. It has similar effectiveness to topical glucocorticoids (e.g., swallowed budesonide, fluticasone), which may be considered as an alternative treatment option in this patient with EoE if other therapies are unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for evaluating esophageal motility disorders (EMD) such as achalasia and distal esophageal spasm. These conditions manifest with dysphagia, which is seen in this patient. However, patients with EMD typically experience dysphagia to both liquids and solids rather than only to solids. Additionally, upper endoscopy in EMD usually shows normal esophageal mucosa rather than the linear, longitudinal furrows and circumferential lesions seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Valganciclovir is the treatment for cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis, which can manifest with dysphagia and epigastric pain, both seen in this patient. However, typical upper endoscopy findings in CMV esophagitis are multiple linear ulcers rather than the linear furrows and circumferential lesions seen here. Moreover, in immunocompetent patients such as this one, CMV infections are usually asymptomatic or mild; CMV esophagitis is more common in immunocompromised individuals (especially those with HIV with low CD4 counts).

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal dilation is indicated in patients with EoE and esophageal strictures if conservative therapy has been ineffective. Although this patient has EoE, no strictures were seen on endoscopy and conservative therapy has not yet been initiated.

F) CORRECT:

Dietary therapy consisting of avoiding potential food allergens (e.g., milk, egg, wheat, soy, and, in this patient, peanuts) is an effective treatment for EoE. Elimination diets are initially maintained for 48 weeks; upon symptom resolution and normalization of esophageal biopsies, foods can be gradually reintroduced. Ideally, dietary therapy should be coordinated with a dietician to prevent nutritional deficiencies. Patients should also carry an epinephrine autoinjector because accidental exposure to an eliminated food allergen may result in anaphylaxis. Other treatment options include acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors and topical glucocorticoids (e.g., budesonide, fluticasone). Dilation of esophageal strictures may be indicated in patients refractory to conservative therapy.
Image Description:

Endoscopic image of the esophagus

Circumferential mucosal lesions (rings/corrugations; examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible.

Yellow lines: longitudinal furrows; Dashed encirclement: Z-line
questions.hint: Dysphagia for solid foods, episodic food impaction, and epigastric pain in a boy with atopy (i.e., asthma, food allergy) and linear furrows and circumferential lesions on upper endoscopy are highly suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). An endoscopic biopsy will typically show an increased number of eosinophils ( 15/HPF).

These findings are consistent with herpes esophagitis. Histopathology is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors in a patient with a history of atopy (allergic rhinitis, asthma) suggest eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). In addition, the findings of trachealization of the esophagus and erythematous longitudinal furrows on upper endoscopy are consistent with EoE. Individuals with EoE may also present with food impaction, reflux, and vomiting. questions.text:
A 43-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease reports a 2-day history of progressive, severe, sharp pain in his chest and retrosternal discomfort when he swallows liquids and solids. He denies foreign-body ingestion.
He has been taking doxycycline for the past week for cellulitis in his left leg. He also takes omeprazole 20 mg daily and denies use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications.
Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. He is hemodynamically stable, and his cellulitis has resolved. His troponin level, electrocardiogram, and chest radiograph are unremarkable.
An upper endoscopy is performed (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following interventions is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with fluticasone 220 g by mouth twice daily
Increase omeprazole to 40 mg twice daily
Initiate treatment with acyclovir 400 mg by mouth five times daily
Initiate treatment with fluconazole 200 mg by mouth daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is used to treat eosinophilic esophagitis, fluconazole is used to treat candidal esophagitis, and acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex infection of the esophagus. Infectious esophagitis is uncommon in immunocompetent patients. In this case, all of these alternative diagnoses are less likely than medication-induced esophagitis, given that symptoms began after the patient took a medication known to cause esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing the omeprazole dose is not beneficial unless reflux is exacerbating the esophagitis, but this is unlikely in a patient with a normal lower esophagus.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is used to treat eosinophilic esophagitis, fluconazole is used to treat candidal esophagitis, and acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex infection of the esophagus. Infectious esophagitis is uncommon in immunocompetent patients. In this case, all of these alternative diagnoses are less likely than medication-induced esophagitis, given that symptoms began after the patient took a medication known to cause esophagitis.

D) CORRECT:

Odynophagia and retrosternal chest pain are classic symptoms of esophagitis induced by a medication. This patients endoscopic findings show esophagitis in the mid- to upper esophagus, rather than in the lower esophagus (where gastroesophageal reflux disease is typically seen). Medication-induced esophagitis can be caused by direct caustic irritation of the esophagus by tetracyclines, bisphosphonates, potassium chloride, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications. Risk factors for pill esophagitis include older age (> 70 years), lack of adequate fluid bolus, delayed peristalsis, recent thoracotomy, and recumbent positioning after pill ingestion. The most appropriate intervention is to discontinue the offending medication in this case, doxycycline. If necessary, an alternative formulation of the same medication can be used, or a different medication can be tried.

Key learning point: The most appropriate intervention for a patient with medication-induced esophagitis is discontinuation of the offending medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is used to treat eosinophilic esophagitis, fluconazole is used to treat candidal esophagitis, and acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex infection of the esophagus. Infectious esophagitis is uncommon in immunocompetent patients. In this case, all of these alternative diagnoses are less likely than medication-induced esophagitis, given that symptoms began after the patient took a medication known to cause esophagitis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man reports experiencing recurrent episodes of dysphagia and food impaction during the past several months. Use of over-the-counter omeprazole has not improved his symptoms. He has a history of food allergies, allergic rhinitis, and asthma. His physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patients recurrent food impactions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achalasia is a rare disorder that would be less likely in this case, especially given the patients risk factors for eosinophilic esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse esophageal spasm can be associated with dysphagia but is typically accompanied by severe chest pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Acid reflux esophagitis can cause dysphagia and food impaction but is unlikely in patients for whom omeprazole has not improved symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis is responsible for about half the cases of recurrent food impaction in nonelderly men. The mechanism of dysphagia is likely related to an inflammatory response that causes remodeling of the esophagus, resulting in the development of rings and strictures. Eosiniophilic esophagitis is strongly associated with allergic conditions such as atopic dermatitis, rhinitis, asthma, and food allergies. Symptoms often occur for months or years before a diagnosis is made.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of recurrent food impaction in a nonelderly man with a history of food allergies, allergic rhinitis, and asthma is eosinophilic esophagitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal candidiasis is unusual in otherwise healthy individuals. It is typically associated with odynophagia and is unlikely to be chronic or to cause food impaction.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman who received a kidney transplant from a deceased donor 5 years ago reports liquid and solid-food dysphagia for the past 5 days. She has odynophagia but no heartburn. She has done well postoperatively and has had no previous gastrointestinal symptoms. Her current immunosuppressive medications are tacrolimus, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil.
At the initial transplant evaluation, the patient had a positive immunoglobulin G titer for cytomegalovirus. Today, her physical examination and laboratory tests, including renal function, are normal, aside from the previously positive cytomegalovirus antibody test.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patients care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole is not indicated in the absence of symptoms of reflux esophagitis, such as heartburn.

B) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is the therapy of choice for CMV-related esophagitis, but empiric treatment is not appropriate given the drugs potential toxicities and side effects, which include thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, anemia, nephrotoxicity, diarrhea, and rash.

C) CORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV)-related esophagitis is the most likely diagnosis in an immunosuppressed kidney transplant recipient who has dysphagia and a positive CMV immunoglobulin G titer initially detected at the time of transplant evaluation. Upper endoscopy should be performed to confirm the presence of viral esophagitis before treatment is initiated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate evaluation for a kidney transplant recipient who has developed dysphagia is upper endoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow test is not the most appropriate next step in this case because confirmation of CMV-related esophagitis requires direct visualization and biopsy of the lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Urea breath testing for Helicobacter pylori is not indicated in a patient whose symptoms are esophageal rather than gastric.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents for follow-up 3 months after starting high-dose omeprazole for retrosternal discomfort and nausea. He reports some improvement in his symptoms but not complete resolution. He continues to experience retrosternal discomfort and, more recently, started having infrequent difficulty with swallowing. He has not had any concerns for choking or food impactions.
His history is otherwise significant only for allergic rhinitis. He currently takes intranasal fluticasone in addition to the omeprazole. He has a brother with asthma and food allergies, and his mother has eczema and gastroesophageal reflux disease.
The patient appears to be well and in no acute distress. He has a blood pressure of 110/74 mm Hg, a heart rate of 89 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while he breathes ambient air. His oropharynx is clear with no tonsillar hypertrophy. Neck examination is normal, with full range of motion and no thyromegaly. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and nontender, with no hepatosplenomegaly.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain an upper gastrointestinal imaging study

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

EoE cannot be diagnosed on the basis of history alone; thus, it would be inappropriate to remove milk from this patients diet without first performing an endoscopy.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with persistent symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux despite use of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), as well as recent-onset intermittent dysphagia. At this stage, he should be evaluated for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), the most common cause of dysphagia in adolescents.

EoE is a chronic immune disorder characterized by esophageal inflammation and dysfunction. The clinical presentation varies by age: Younger children often present with nausea, vomiting, and feeding difficulties, whereas older children and adolescents are more likely to present with symptoms of reflux, epigastric pain, dysphagia, or food impaction.

EoE should be considered in any pediatric patient who has symptoms of chronic reflux that fail to respond to PPI therapy but especially in patients with a history of allergies, asthma, allergic rhinitis, or atopic dermatitis, because EoE is strongly associated with these conditions. Although the pathophysiology of EoE is not well understood, it is believed to be an allergic response to an environmental allergen, typically a food, but not an immunoglobulin E (IgE) response.

Diagnosis of EoE requires that the patient have:

Symptoms of esophageal dysfunction
Inflammation on esophageal biopsy, with eosinophilic predominance (15 eosinophils per high-power field)
No other known causes for the esophageal eosinophilia

Given these criteria, esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the only means of diagnosing EoE. Because both gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and EoE may respond to PPI therapy, a response to such therapy may not be useful in distinguishing between the two conditions. EGD should be performed after a trial of PPI therapy to help rule out gastroesophageal reflux as the sole cause of mucosal changes or eosinophils found in the esophagus.

The endoscopic findings suggestive of EoE include concentric rings, linear furrowing, and white exudates. EoE may be patchy, so multiple biopsies should be performed.

Treatment options for EoE include both dietary modification (aimed at identifying the allergic trigger) and medical therapy. The goal of either approach is to improve symptoms and histology.

Dietary options include eliminating all six of the most common food allergens (milk, soy, eggs, wheat, nuts, and fish), selectively eliminating one of the most common food allergens, or introducing an elemental diet. Specific food restriction may be augmented by allergy testing (skin and blood), but the results may not be accurate, given that EoE is not a predominantly IgE-mediated process.
Medical therapy for EoE is with topical glucocorticoids, such as swallowed fluticasone propionate or viscous budesonide. Dupilumab (a biologic agent targeting interleukin 4R-alpha) has also shown efficacy in treating EoE.

Treatment response is monitored with repeat endoscopy. Patients should be encouraged to maintain consistent therapy, because EoE is a chronic condition that can lead to fibrosis and esophageal strictures if left untreated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate evaluation for a pediatric patient with symptoms of chronic reflux that fail to respond to an adequate trial of proton pump inhibitors is esophagogastroduodenoscopy to evaluate for eosinophilic esophagitis.

C) INCORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal (GI) imaging study can be helpful if there is concern for significant esophageal stricture secondary to advanced EoE. However, a significant stricture seems unlikely in this case, given that the patient only recently began experiencing intermittent dysphagia; endoscopy is a better next step.

An upper GI imaging study can also be beneficial in diagnosing achalasia, a progressive neurologic condition that causes dysphagia when the lower esophageal sphincter is unable to relax properly. Although achalasia can occur during adolescence, the incidence is much lower than that of EoE in this age group.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest CT can be useful if there are concerns for anatomic abnormalities or for external esophageal compression. However, in this case, the patient has a history of retrosternal discomfort, nausea, and dysphagia, making a luminal disease (such as EoE) more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient did not respond to an adequate trial of omeprazole and now reports intermittent dysphagia; thus, it is necessary to pursue endoscopy and consider pathologies other than gastroesophageal reflux as the cause of his symptoms. Simply switching to a new PPI would be inadequate.

Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) can directly injure the esophageal mucosa in case of prolonged contact and cause drug-induced esophagitis. The most appropriate next step in the management of this condition is to discontinue the offending drug, if possible, and observe for symptom improvement. Most cases will then heal without further intervention. To minimize recurrence, patients should switch to liquid formulations or take the medication with liquids or meals to minimize the risk of the drug tablet sticking in the esophagus. Remaining upright for 30 minutes after taking the drug is also effective. Other common medications that can cause drug-induced esophagitis include antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines, clindamycin), NSAIDs, potassium chloride, quinidine, and iron compounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is an antifungal drug used to treat Candida albicans infections, which can cause esophagitis. However, upper endoscopy of Candida esophagitis classically shows small, raised, white plaques and oral thrush, not a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as amlodipine induce muscle relaxation and decrease lower esophageal sphincter tone, which can increase the risk of developing drug-induced esophagitis. However, CCBs do not directly cause this condition; discontinuation of amlodipine is not the most appropriate next step in the management.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal drug used to treat Candida albicans infections, which can cause esophagitis. This patient has an increased risk of developing fungal infections due to the chronic use of a steroid inhaler for asthma control. However, upper endoscopy of Candida esophagitis classically shows small, raised, white plaques and oral thrush, not a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa.
questions.hint: This patient has medication-induced esophagitis, a condition that typically manifests with retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia as seen in this case. Dysphagia is another common manifestation. The characteristic finding on upper endoscopy is a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa, often located at a site of anatomic narrowing (e.g., the gastroesophageal junction).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of difficulty swallowing, accompanied by a burning sensation in his chest. He often feels that solid foods get "stuck" in his throat when eating. He has used over-the-counter antacids and omeprazole for 2 months with minimal relief. His medical history includes allergic rhinitis and asthma. Upper endoscopy reveals circumferential mucosal lesions and erythematous longitudinal furrows. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors raise concern for cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis. CMV esophagitis most commonly manifests in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Moreover, endoscopic evaluation of CMV esophagitis would show large linear ulcerations in the distal esophagus that are typically shallow, which are not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Heartburn and dysphagia should raise concern for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). However, symptoms of GERD usually improve with proton pump inhibitor therapy. GERD commonly affects the distal esophagus, which may be normal or show evidence of esophagitis; endoscopic evaluation of the upper esophagus is often normal.

C) CORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors in a patient with a history of atopy (allergic rhinitis, asthma) suggest eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). In addition, the findings of trachealization of the esophagus and erythematous longitudinal furrows on upper endoscopy are consistent with EoE. Individuals with EoE may also present with food impaction, reflux, and vomiting. Diagnosis is confirmed by esophageal biopsy showing inflammation with 15 eosinophils/HPF and exclusion of other causes of or contributors to esophageal eosinophilia (see Differential diagnoses of eosinophilic esophagitis). Initial treatment of EoE includes avoidance of food triggers, topical glucocorticoids (e.g., PO fluticasone PO budesonide), and mechanical dilation in the setting of esophageal stricture.

Key learning point: Eosinophilic esophagitis presents with dysphagia and heartburn unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors, especially in patients with atopic conditions, and is characterized endoscopically by mucosal rings and longitudinal furrows.

D) INCORRECT:

Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors should raise concern for candida esophagitis. Candida esophagitis is most commonly seen in individuals who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Additionally, endoscopic evaluation of candida esophagitis would reveal white mucosal plaque-like lesions, which are not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Dysphagia is seen in individuals with achalasia. Unlike in this patient, an endoscopic evaluation is typically normal or may show erythematous mucosa, dilated esophagus with retained food particles, and increased resistance of lower esophageal sphincter during passage with an endoscope. None of these findings is present here.
questions.hint: Diagnosis of this condition requires symptoms of esophageal dysfunction and histopathologic confirmation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of severe retrosternal chest pain. She also reports pain when swallowing solid food and medications. questions.text: A 45-year-old man with acute myeloid leukemia presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of severe odynophagia and retrosternal chest pain. He completed his most recent chemotherapy cycle 2 weeks ago. He reports difficulty swallowing solids and liquids due to pain. Vital signs are BP, 120/80; P, 82; R, 18; T, 37.0C (98.6F). Physical examination shows white plaques in the oral cavity that can be scrapped off. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is used for cytomegalovirus esophagitis. However, this patient's presentation (white plaques) suggests a fungal cause of infectious esophagitis, requiring alternative treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole is an H2 antagonist used for gastroesophageal reflux disease. This patient is immunocompromised and has features (odynophagia, chest pain, white plaques) consistent with infectious esophagitis. Therefore, an alternative treatment is required.

C) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used for gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, this patient's presentation (odynophagia, chest pain, white plaques) and immunocompromised status are more consistent with infectious esophagitis, requiring alternative treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation (odynophagia, chest pain, white plaques) and immunocompromised status strongly suggest esophageal candidiasis, a type of infectious esophagitis caused by Candida spp. Empiric antifungal therapy with fluconazole is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes esophagitis. However, this patient's presentation (white plaques) suggests a fungal cause of infectious esophagitis, requiring alternative treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office due to a long-standing history of difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports multiple episodes of food getting stuck in his chest, requiring him to drink large amounts of water to pass the bolus. He has a history of asthma and seasonal allergic rhinitis. An 8-week trial of a high-dose proton pump inhibitor provided no relief of his symptoms. An upper endoscopy is performed and shows multiple concentric rings and linear furrows throughout the esophagus. Biopsies are taken. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Schatzki ring is a common cause of intermittent solid food dysphagia and food impaction. However, it is a single, thin mucosal ring located at the gastroesophageal junction. The endoscopic finding of multiple concentric rings throughout the esophagus is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) can cause dysphagia, often due to peptic strictures. However, this patient's symptoms did not improve after an 8-week trial of a high-dose proton pump inhibitor, making uncomplicated GERD less likely. Additionally, the endoscopic findings of multiple concentric rings and furrows are not typical for GERD, which more commonly presents with erosions, ulcerations, or a normal-appearing mucosa.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for eosinophilic esophagitis, an immune-mediated inflammatory condition. Key features include a young man with a history of atopic disease (asthma, allergies) presenting with solid food dysphagia and food impaction. The endoscopic findings of multiple concentric rings (trachealization or corrugated esophagus) and linear furrows are highly characteristic. Failure to respond to a high-dose proton pump inhibitor trial also supports the diagnosis. The diagnosis is confirmed by esophageal biopsies showing 15 eosinophils per high-power field. Treatment involves dietary elimination, topical corticosteroids, or biologic agents.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious esophagitis can present with dysphagia. Common causes include Candida, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and herpes simplex virus (HSV). However, infectious esophagitis typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals, and this patient has no stated risk factors. Furthermore, the endoscopic appearance is different: Candida causes white plaques, CMV causes large linear ulcers, and HSV causes small, well-circumscribed ulcers. These findings are inconsistent with concentric rings and furrows.

E) INCORRECT:

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder that causes dysphagia to both solids and liquids due to impaired lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. While it causes dysphagia and food sticking, the endoscopic findings of concentric rings and linear furrows are not characteristic. Endoscopy in achalasia may show a dilated, food-filled esophagus, but the diagnosis is confirmed with esophageal manometry.
questions.hint: The endoscopic findings of multiple concentric rings are highly characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with HIV presents with a 2-week history of severe pain upon swallowing. He reports the sensation of food getting stuck in his chest, which has led to a 5-lb weight loss. He has been nonadherent to antiretroviral therapy. His temperature is 37.5C (99.5F). A photograph of the oropharynx is shown.  His most recent CD4 count was 75 cells/mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Oral fluconazole is the first-line treatment due to its high efficacy against Candida species, excellent oral bioavailability, and favorable safety profile. Because the infection extends beyond the oropharynx into the esophagus, systemic antifungal therapy is required. Empiric treatment is the standard of care in this clinical scenario, with endoscopy reserved for patients who do not respond to initial therapy or when the diagnosis is uncertain. Treatment is typically continued for 1421 days.

B) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is a topical antifungal agent effective for treating oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush). However, it is not absorbed systemically and therefore has no efficacy for esophageal candidiasis. This patient's symptoms of odynophagia and dysphagia indicate esophageal involvement, which requires systemic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. While HSV can cause infectious esophagitis in immunocompromised patients, the clinical finding of white, cottage cheese-like plaques is classic for Candida, not HSV. HSV esophagitis typically manifests with well-demarcated, 'punched-out' ulcers on endoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum systemic antifungal agent. While effective, it is reserved for severe, disseminated fungal infections or for cases of Candida esophagitis that are refractory to initial azole therapy. It is not used as a first-line agent for uncomplicated Candida esophagitis due to its significant potential for toxicity, including nephrotoxicity and infusion-related reactions.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of odynophagia and oral thrush (white, cottage cheese-like plaques on the oropharynx and tongue) with a CD4 count < 100 cells/mm is highly suggestive of Candida esophagitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with a 1-week history of painful swallowing and a burning sensation in his chest. He recently completed a 14-day course of oral prednisone for a severe poison ivy rash. He is afebrile and hemodynamically stable. A photograph of the oropharynx is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole troches are a form of topical therapy used for mild oropharyngeal candidiasis. The troche dissolves in the mouth, delivering medication directly to the affected oral mucosa. Topical clotrimazole is not systemically absorbed and is ineffective for treating Candida esophagitis, which is the primary concern due to this patient's painful swallowing.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation with oral thrush, odynophagia, and retrosternal burning is highly suggestive of esophageal candidiasis, especially considering his risk factors of poorly controlled diabetes and recent steroid use. Esophageal candidiasis requires systemic antifungal therapy. Oral fluconazole is the first-line treatment for this condition in patients who can tolerate oral medications. It is highly effective against most Candida species, is well-absorbed, and achieves therapeutic concentrations in the esophageal tissue.

While endoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis, empiric treatment is often initiated in patients with typical symptoms and oral thrush.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous amphotericin B is a potent systemic antifungal reserved for severe, disseminated, or fluconazole-refractory fungal infections. This patient is hemodynamically stable and afebrile. Therefore, initiating therapy with a highly toxic agent like amphotericin B is inappropriate. It is not a first-line choice for uncomplicated Candida esophagitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Nystatin oral suspension is a topical antifungal agent effective for uncomplicated oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush). However, it is not systemically absorbed and therefore would not adequately treat the esophageal component of the infection, which is suggested by this patient's odynophagia and chest burning. This therapy is insufficient for disease that has spread beyond the oropharynx.
questions.hint: This patient's odynophagia and burning chest sensation suggest the infection extends beyond the oropharynx, which requires a systemic approach to treatment.
